annotation.TEXT: Extra precautions. That clockwork mouse pushed me back into the pit too many times during my practice runs, so I wasn't about to take any chances here.
You can actually reach this music sheet with just the Mobile Gear alone. The Propeller Dagger isn't a requirement to obtain it, but it certainly does make things easier.

Chester will sell you the Mobile Gear for 3,000 gold in this stage. The Mobile Gear itself acts more like a support item than an actual weapon. Using it produces a gear-platform that travels along the ground once you jump on it. Aside from gaining a good amount of speed, the platform is also highly reactive to the area around it, as it can automatically hop when it reaches an edge. It can also hurt enemies it comes into contact with (and you can actually get an achievement for killing 5 enemies with a single use of it), but it tends to work out better as a support relic either way.

Tinker Knight is, at first glance, a complete joke when you first fight him. The only things he can do are move, occasionally trip, and throw his wrench like a slow-acting boomerang. He also takes double damage from your Shovel Blade as well. Granted, he does have a more threatening attack where he throws out several wrenches at once, but it's somewhat short ranged and usually only triggered after you damage him enough.

With that done, here's Tinker Knight's level (or as I like to call it: "The Revenge of Metal Man"). This stage's main gimmick involves conveyor belts and several new forms of moving platforms. It also introduces a few new enemy types, mainly in the form of Gear Wizards (which send out cogs that travel along the ground), and Clockwork Mice (who lunge at you if you get too close, which can become very dangerous depending on your position when they attack).

Note: Phantom Striker actually has different responses and money rewards depending on how you fight him. If you get hit too many times and/or the battle go on for too long, he'll give you a rather small amount of silver coins and will say that "you still need training to overcome what lies ahead." Taking very few hits and beating him quickly however will give you the dialogue prompt you just saw, along with a bunch of diamonds as an additional reward.

Before I move on to Tinker Knight's stage, it's time to deal with the next wandering NPC that suddenly emerged from last time (since I did multiple takes on this episode, his position has changed a bit, but the fight/arena is still the same).

Of course, such an easy fight wouldn't suffice for the end of a stage like this one. Tinker Knight's second phase is obviously a bit more difficult to deal with. The only way you can hurt him is by hitting his exposed head. The most ideal way to do so is to use his projectiles to bounce up to him and get into a rhythm of hitting him in between the projectiles fired from his shoulder turret, or (if you have enough magic left) use the Throwing Anchor on him.

Phantom Striker is the fourth Guest Director enemy seen so far, and is the final wandering map-based opponent you'll encounter. Fittingly enough, he's also the most difficult of the optional bosses. Phantom Striker is highly reactive to everything you do, making this more of an actual duel rather than a pattern-based fight. He can deflect projectiles and even block out basic attacks at times, along with teleporting and firing his own projectiles. He can also summon a constant wind effect (not seen in this video) if the fight goes on for too long.

I was a bit late with my timing when I realized I could have used the Phase Locket to avoid this. After you hit him about 7 times, he'll use a new attack where he charges at you (which is the only time the main body can hurt you), followed by a rain of projectiles starting from the left side.
